SuperGenPass is a different kind of password manager: instead of randomly generating and storing passwords, it combines a website’s domain and your master password to generate a unique password for each site you visit using a strong cryptographic hash.


In addition to launching it directly, in Chrome go to: Menu → Share Page → SuperGenPass.


To use on your computer, please see the parent project: https://chriszarate.github.io/supergenpass/ . This has both a handy bookmarklet as well as a stand-alone Javascript page. The author of Android SuperGenPass highly recommends finding a plugin for your browser instead of the bookmarklet as it’s more secure.


This app also includes a strong PIN generation algorithm. It’s a slightly modified version of RFC4226 HOTP (modified to work with domains instead of numerical counters) and is designed to never generate easily-guessable pins, such as 1234, 0000, 1985, 8675309, or 0007. See the source code for more details.


This project is Free Software/Open Source and is licensed under the GNU GPL Version 3. You can get the source for this application from https://github.com/xxv/SuperGenPass


Final word of caution: while SGP generates strong passwords, if a malicious website knows that you’re using SGP and has access to the plain-text of your password for their site, they could attempt to brute-force your master password. Therefore it is recommended to make sure your master password is also strong or that you use a salt. One great technique for such a password is to use the first letters of a favorite phrase. For example, “When on Earth, do as the humans do?” could become “W0EdatHd”.

Tap a writable NFC tag now to store the currently-entered master password on it in plain text.

When you scan the tag from the main screen, it will be added to the end of the master password form. You can use this just like the password salt: store part of the master password in your head and part on the tag (or all on the tag if you prefer). Additionally, you can scan the tag at any time to bring up the app with the password pre-filled.
